name: Austin E. Lathrop
notes: Ran for city council and was named mayor by virtue of being to top vote-getter in the election. Lathrop declined any more terms as mayor, but continued serving on the council until 1914<a href="#cite_note-Tower-5">[5]

name: Will H. Chase
notes: Multiple sources state he served as mayor of Cordova for 24 terms, not necessarily consecutive, though.<a href="#cite_note-consortiumlibrary-8">[8] Born in 1874 and died in 1965.<a href="#cite_note-alaska-9">[9][not in citation given] Served 18 years as mayor by 1952.<a href="#cite_note-fultonhistory-10">[10] By 1911 he had already served as mayor in some capacity.<a href="#cite_note-google-11">[11] By 1938 he had already served 12 times as mayor.<a href="#cite_note-fultonhistory2-12">[12] Was elected mayor in 1910 along with a "practically new council."<a href="#cite_note-chroniclingamerica.loc.gov-4">[4]

name: Bob Van Brocklin
notes: Committed suicide several years after the oil spill.<a href="#cite_note-suzuki-22">[22]

name: Kelly Weaverling
notes: First Green Party mayor in U.S.<a href="#cite_note-23">[23]

name: Margy Johnson
notes: First woman elected mayor of Cordova <a href="#cite_note-25">[25]

name: Nancy Bird
notes: "... served for about 4 months as Acting Mayor in 2003." <a href="#cite_note-29">[29]
